{{About|the band|piano keys|piano keys|Chopin's Étude commonly known as Black Keys| Étude Op. 10, No. 5 (Chopin)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Black Keys | image = Black-keys-sxsw-montage.jpg | image_size = 250 | landscape = yes | caption = The Black Keys performing at [[South by Southwest]] in 2010 | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Akron, Ohio]], United States | genre = [[Garage rock]], [[blues rock]], [[indie rock]] | years_active = {{Start date|2001}}–present | label = [[Alive Naturalsound Records|Alive]], [[Fat Possum Records|Fat Possum]], [[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]], [[V2 Records|V2]] | website = {{URL|www.theblackkeys.com}} | associated_acts = ''[[Blakroc]]'', [[Drummer (band)|Drummer]], [[The Rentals]], [[Danger Mouse]] | current_members = [[Dan Auerbach]]
[[Patrick Carney]] | past_members = }} '''The Black Keys''' is an American [[Rock music|rock]] duo formed in [[Akron, Ohio]] in 2001. The group consists of [[Dan Auerbach]] ([[guitar]], [[Singing|vocals]]) and [[Patrick Carney]] ([[Drum kit|drums]]). The duo began as an [[Independent music|independent]] act, recording music in basements and self-producing their records, before they eventually emerged as one of the most popular [[garage rock]] artists during a second wave of the genre's revival in the [[2010s in music|2010s]]. The band's raw [[blues rock]] sound draws heavily from Auerbach's [[blues]] influences, including [[Junior Kimbrough]], [[Howlin' Wolf]], and [[Robert Johnson]]. Originally friends from their childhood, Auerbach and Carney founded the group after dropping out of college. After signing with [[Independent record label|indie label]] [[Alive Naturalsound Records|Alive]], they released their debut album, ''[[The Big Come Up]]'' (2002), which earned them a new deal with [[Fat Possum Records]]. Over the next decade, the Black Keys built an underground fanbase through extensive touring of small clubs, frequent album releases and music festival appearances, and substantial [[music licensing|licensing]] of their songs. Their third album, ''[[Rubber Factory]]'' (2004), received critical acclaim and boosted the band's profile, eventually leading to a record deal with major label [[Nonesuch Records]] in 2006. After self-producing and recording their first four records in makeshift studios, the duo completed ''[[Attack & Release]]'' (2008) in a professional studio and hired producer [[Danger Mouse]], a frequent collaborator with the band. The group's commercial breakthrough came in 2010 with ''[[Brothers (The Black Keys album)|Brothers]]'', which along with its popular single "[[Tighten Up (The Black Keys song)|Tighten Up]]", won three [[Grammy Awards]]. Their 2011 follow-up ''[[El Camino (The Black Keys album)|El Camino]]'' received strong reviews and peaked at number two on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, leading to the first arena concert tour of the band's career, the [[El Camino Tour]]. The album and its hit single "[[Lonely Boy (The Black Keys song)|Lonely Boy]]" won three Grammy Awards. In 2014, they released their eighth album, ''[[Turn Blue (album)|Turn Blue]]'', their first number-one record in the US and Australia. ==Career== ===Early history=== Guitarist/vocalist [[Dan Auerbach]] and drummer [[Patrick Carney]] first met when they were eight or nine years old while living in the same neighborhood of [[Akron, Ohio]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2010/06/black_keys_drummer_patrick_car.html|title=Hilarious Black Keys Drummer Patrick Carney on Not Growing a Beard, Damon Dash, and Danger Mouse|work=[[New York (magazine)|Vulture]]|publisher=New York Media LLC|first=Nishan|last=Gopalan|date=June 3, 2010|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} While attending [[Firestone High School]], they became friends, though they were part of different crowds{{cite web|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2011/11/the-black-keys-brothers-in-arms/|title=The Black Keys: Brothers In Arms|work=[[American Songwriter]]|first=Andrew|last=Leahey|date=November 1, 2011|accessdate=December 8, 2011}}—Auerbach was captain of the high school [[soccer]] team, while Carney was a social outcast.{{cite journal|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-rise-of-the-black-keys-20120119|title=Black Keys Rising|journal=[[Rolling Stone]]|first=Brian|last=Hiatt|pages=38–41, 66|issue=1148|date=January 19, 2012|accessdate=February 17, 2012}} Encouraged by a mutual friend,{{cite news|url=http://www.music.yahoo.ca/read/news/12175063|title=Don't Call the Black Keys 'Garage Blues'|first=Bret|last=Gladstone|work=[[AP Online]]|agency=Associated Press|date=November 24, 2004|accessdate=June 7, 2012}} the duo began [[jam session|jamming]] together in 1996, as Auerbach was learning guitar at the time and Carney owned a [[Multitrack recording|four-track recorder]] and a drum set.{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/01/31/133276978/the-fresh-air-interview-the-black-keys|title=The Fresh Air Interview: The Black Keys|work=[[NPR Music]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=January 31, 2011|accessdate=February 2, 2012}}{{cite journal|title=Fuzz freak: the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach on the majesty of muck|journal=[[Guitar Player]]|first=Jimmy|last=Leslie|date=November 1, 2003}} After graduating, both briefly attended the [[University of Akron]] before dropping out.{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/life_and_entertainment/2012/03/04/keys-success.html|title=Retro-rock duo from Akron now playing to arena crowds|work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]]|publisher=The Dispatch Printing Company|first=Kevin|last=Joy|date=March 6, 2012|accessdate=March 13, 2012}} ===Formation, ''The Big Come Up'', and ''Thickfreakness'' (2001–2003)=== Auerbach attempted to make a living from performing at small bars in town, but realized he would not be able to book shows in other cities without a [[demo (music)|demo]]. To record one, he asked for help from Carney, who agreed to provide recording equipment and allow his basement to be used if Auerbach recruited the other musicians. However, none of Auerbach's backing band showed up on the recording date. Instead, Carney and Auerbach jammed, eventually leading to the duo forming a band in mid-2001.{{cite journal|url=http://www.spin.com/#articles/blues-explosion-black-keys|title=Blues Explosion!|journal=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|first=Dorian|last=Lynskey|date=September 2010|accessdate=August 30, 2012|pages=60–63|volume=26|issue=8}} Together, they recorded a six-song demo consisting of "old [[blues]] rip-offs and words made up on the spot". After soliciting the demo to a dozen [[record label]]s, they received and accepted an offer from a small [[Independent record label|indie label]] in Los Angeles called [[Alive Naturalsound Records|Alive]], as it was "the only label that would sign [them] without having to see [them] first".{{cite news|title=Into the Black; Keys unlock a raw, bluesy sound|newspaper=[[Boston Herald]]|publisher=Herald Media Inc.|first=Larry|last=Katz|date=October 7, 2003|at=sec. The Edge, p. 47}} According to an interview on [[NPR]]'s ''[[Fresh Air]]'', the group's name "the Black Keys" came from a schizophrenic artist named Alfred McMoore that the pair knew; he would leave incoherent messages on their answering machines referring to their fathers as "[[Black key|black keys]]" such as "D flat" when he was upset with them.{{cite episode|title=The Fresh Air Interview: The Black Keys|url=http://www.npr.org/player/v2/mediaPlayer.html?action=1&t=1&islist=false&id=133276978&m=133369165|series=Fresh Air|serieslink=Fresh Air|credits=[[Terry Gross]] (presenter)|network=[[NPR]]|station=[[WHYY-FM]]|city=Philadelphia|airdate=2011-01-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/news/sept-28-2009-akron-artist-alfred-mcmoore-dies-cried-for-people-he-never-met-1.136667|title=Akron artist Alfred McMoore dies; cried for people he never met |work=Ohio.com|publisher=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|date=September 28, 2009 |accessdate=April 22, 2012}} The band's debut album, ''[[The Big Come Up]]'', was recorded entirely in Carney's basement on an [[8-track tape]] recorder in [[lo-fi]] and was released in May 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/1067489/the-black-keys-el-camino-track-by-track-review|title=The Black Keys' 'El Camino': Track-by-Track Review|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|first=Jillian|last=Mapes|date=December 6, 2011|accessdate=February 19, 2013}} The album, a mix of eight original tracks and five cover songs, forged a raw [[blues rock]] sound for the group; the covers included tracks originally by blues musicians [[Muddy Waters]], [[Junior Kimbrough]], and [[R. L. Burnside]]. Two singles, covers of the traditional blues standard "[[Leavin' Trunk/She Said, She Said|Leavin' Trunk]]" and [[The Beatles]]' song "[[She Said She Said|She Said, She Said]]", were released as an [[extended play|EP]]. The track "I'll Be Your Man" would later be used as the theme song for the [[HBO]] series ''[[Hung (TV series)|Hung]]''. A week after the album was released, the duo played their first live show at Cleveland's Beachland Ballroom and Tavern to an audience of, in Auerbach's estimation, four people. In order to help fund a tour, Auerbach and Carney took jobs [[Lawn mower|mowing lawns]] for a landlord.{{cite episode|title=Keeping it Primitive with The Black Keys|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-131704772.html|series=Morning Edition|serieslink=Morning Edition|credits=[[Steve Inskeep|Inskeep, Steve]] (presenter)|network=[[NPR]]|airdate=2006-11-24}} Although ''The Big Come Up'' sold poorly, it gained a cult following and attracted attention from critics, eventually landing the group a record deal with [[Fat Possum Records]].{{cite web|url=http://readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=370394|title=The Black Keys hitting all the right notes|work=[[Reading Eagle]]|publisher=Reading Eagle Company|first=Gary|last=Graff|date=March 11, 2012|accessdate=March 13, 2012}} Within days of signing to Fat Possum, The Black Keys completed their second album, ''[[Thickfreakness]]''. It was recorded in Carney's basement in a single 14-hour session in December 2002, an approach necessitated because the group spent its small [[advance payment]] from Fat Possum on rent.{{cite AV media notes|title=Thickfreakness|others=The Black Keys|year=2003|publisher=[[Fat Possum Records]]|type=CD booklet}} The group had recorded sessions with producer Jeff Saltzman in San Francisco but ultimately aborted them, as they were unhappy with the results, which they said too closely resembled "modern-rock radio". In March 2003, the group played at one of its first music festivals, [[South by Southwest]] in Austin, Texas, after driving for nearly 24 hours from Akron.{{cite web|url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/2003-03-19/music/sxsw-2003/|title=SXSW 2003|work=[[Seattle Weekly|SeattleWeekly.com]]|publisher=[[Village Voice Media]]|first=Leah|last=Greenblatt|date=March 19, 2003|accessdate=August 23, 2012}} Much as they did for the festival, Carney and Auerbach spent their early tour days driving themselves from show to show in a 1994 [[Chrysler]] van they nicknamed the "Gray Ghost".{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/the330entertainment/abram/march-13-2003-black-keys-head-for-south-by-southwest-success-in-their-sights-1.274353|title=March 13, 2003: Black Keys head for South By Southwest, success in their sights|work=Ohio.com|publisher=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|first=Malcolm X|last=Abram|date=March 14, 2012|accessdate=August 23, 2012}} ''Thickfreakness'' was released in April 2003 and received positive reviews from critics. The record spawned three singles: "[[Set You Free (The Black Keys song)|Set You Free]]", "[[Hard Row]]", and a cover of [[Richard Berry (musician)|Richard Berry]]'s "[[Have Love, Will Travel]]". The other cover from the album was Junior Kimbrough's "Everywhere I Go". ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' later named ''Thickfreakness'' the third-best album of 2003.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2001842_2001828_2002002,00.html|title=Top 10 Everything 2003: Music – 3. Thickfreakness by The Black Keys|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time.com]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|first=Josh|last=Tyrangiel|authorlink=Josh Tyrangiel|date=December 18, 2003|accessdate=June 8, 2012}} That year, the duo received a lucrative offer of ₤200,000 to [[music licensing|license]] one of their songs for use in an English mayonnaise advertisement. At the suggestion of their [[talent manager|manager]], they rejected the offer for fear of being perceived as "[[selling out|sell-outs]]" and alienating their fan base.{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2011/dec/01/black-keys-interview?INTCMP=SRCH|title='We've put in more hours than anyone': The Black Keys interviewed|work=[[The Guardian|guardian.co.uk]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|first=Dave|last=Simpson|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=February 6, 2012}}{{cite episode|title=The Black Keys: No longer the underdogs|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=7406190n&tag=mncol;lst;2|accessdate=April 22, 2012|series=CBS News Sunday Morning|serieslink=CBS News Sunday Morning|network=[[CBS]]|credits=[[Anthony Mason (journalist)|Mason, Anthony]] (reporter)|date=April 22, 2012|season=33}} The band toured extensively throughout 2003, playing its first dates outside of the United States and opening concerts for [[Sleater-Kinney]], [[Beck (musician)|Beck]], and [[Dashboard Confessional]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/black-keys-open-factory-20040624|title=Black Keys Open 'Factory'|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|first=Andrew|last=Dansby|date=June 24, 2004|accessdate=March 11, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/69457/black-keys-unlock-world-tour-new-single|title=Black Keys Unlock World Tour, New Single|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=February 13, 2013}} However, exhaustion had set in by the end of the year, forcing the band to cancel European tour dates. In August, the group made its national television debut on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' and performed at the [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1215321/|title=Episode dated 8 August 2003 (8 Aug. 2003)|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=February 13, 2013}} As fellow garage band [[The White Stripes]] grew in popularity, The Black Keys drew comparisons to them—sometimes as a derivative act—since both groups had two-piece lineups, Midwest origins, bluesy sounds, and names with colors.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/08/arts/music/08KEYS.html|title=ROCK REVIEW; A Blues Duo Seeking Virtue In Plainness|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Ben|last=Ratliff|date=July 8, 2004|accessdate=March 11, 2012}} In September, The Black Keys released a split-EP with [[The Six Parts Seven]] titled ''[[The Six Parts Seven/The Black Keys EP]]'', featuring one song by The Six Parts Seven and three songs by The Black Keys. ===''Rubber Factory'', ''Magic Potion'', and other releases (2004–2007)=== The Black Keys released an EP titled ''[[The Moan]]'' on January 19, 2004, featuring "Have Love Will Travel", an alternate version of "Heavy Soul," and two covers. The group found itself struggling to sell records or gain airplay of their songs on the radio, and they were not making much money either; they had to absorb a $3,000 loss from a European tour.{{cite journal|title=Black Keys Rising|journal=[[Rolling Stone]]|first=Brian|last=Hiatt|pages=38–41, 66|issue=1148}} Frustrated with their lack of success, the band relented and decided to begin licensing their music, beginning with the song "Set You Free" in a [[Nissan Motors|Nissan]] automobile commercial. It was the first of an eventual 300-plus song placements in television shows, films, TV commercials, and video games. The group played several high-profile musical festivals in the first half of the 2004, including [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/black-keys-on-their-first-coachella-as-headliners-20120420|title=Black Keys on Their First Coachella as Headliners|work=Rolling Stone|first=Simon|last=Vozick-Levinson|date=April 20, 2012|accessdate=May 1, 2013}} and [[Bonnaroo Music Festival|Bonnaroo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2004/06/12/bonnaroo_fest_off_to_a_scorching_start/?camp=pm|title=Bonnaroo fest off to a scorching start|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Tom|last=Kielty|date=June 12, 2004|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} [[File:Dan auerbach - black keys.jpg|thumb|Auerbach with the Black Keys in December 2006]] For their third album, ''[[Rubber Factory]]'', the band was forced to find a new recording location, as the building that housed their basement studio was sold by its landlord. They created a makeshift studio in a former [[tire]]-manufacturing factory in Akron, and recorded from January to May 2004.{{cite AV media notes|title=Rubber Factory|titlelink=Rubber Factory|others=The Black Keys|type=booklet|year=2004|publisher=[[Fat Possum Records]]|id=80379-2}} The album was released in September and became the group's first record to chart on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], reaching number 143.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-black-keys-mn0000755918/awards|title=The Black Keys – Awards|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} ''Rubber Factory'' received critical acclaim and was named one of the year's best albums by ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' and ''[[The New Yorker]]''.{{cite news|title=Black Keys retain bare-bones blues and rock combo|newspaper=[[Omaha World-Herald]]|first=Niz|last=Proskocil|date=November 30, 2006}} Two singles were released, "[[10 A.M. Automatic]]" and the double A-side "[['Till I Get My Way/Girl Is on My Mind]]". Comedian [[David Cross]] directed the music video for "10 A.M. Automatic".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66216/black-keys-rock-the-elderly-in-new-video|title=Black Keys Rock The Elderly In New Video|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=October 5, 2004|accessdate=March 17, 2013}} The duo promoted the album with tours in North America, Europe, and Australia.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66216/black-keys-rock-the-elderly-in-new-video|title=Black Keys Rock The Elderly In New Video|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=February 13, 2013}} In 2005, the band released their first live video album, ''[[Live (The Black Keys album)|Live]]'', recorded at [[The Metro Theatre]] in Sydney, Australia on March 18, 2005. In July, they played at the [[Lollapalooza]] music festival.{{cite news|title=basic PROGRAMMING // It's not an alt-rock fest anymore, but it's fan-friendly and sounds good|newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|first=Jim|last=DeRogatis|authorlink=Jim DeRogatis|date=July 25, 2005|page=42}} On May 2, 2006, the Black Keys released ''[[Chulahoma: The Songs of Junior Kimbrough]]'', a 6-track album of cover versions of songs by Junior Kimbrough. It was the band's final release with the independent label Fat Possum. Having fulfilled their two-album contract, the band signed with the major label [[Nonesuch Records]].{{cite news|title=Black Keys retexture the blues|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Joan|last=Anderman|date=October 31, 2006}} Later in May, the group released its second live album, ''[[Live in Austin, TX (The Black Keys album)|Live in Austin, TX]]''—also known as ''Thickfreakness in Austin''—which was recorded in 2003. The group's music appeared in several television commercials over the course of the year; among the companies to license its music were [[Sony]], Nissan, and [[Victoria's Secret]], which used "The Desperate Man" in a lingerie commercial featuring [[Heidi Klum]].{{cite news|title=Lingerie ad uses smooth touch of Akron: Black Keys song featured in Heidi Klum TV spot|newspaper=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|first=Mary|last=Ethridge|date=August 2, 2006}} Despite having the resources of a major record label available to them, the group elected to return to recording in Carney's basement for its fourth studio album, ''[[Magic Potion (album)|Magic Potion]]''. Released on September 12, the album was the group's first release on Nonesuch,{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2006/09/10/impressions_pop_recordings/?comments=all|title=Impressions: Pop Recordings|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|first=Joan|last=Anderman|date=September 10, 2006|accessdate=June 8, 2012}} as well as its first album to comprise all original songs. Three singles were issued: "[[You're the One (The Black Keys song)|You're the One]]", "[[Your Touch]]", and "[[Just Got To Be]]". In support of ''Magic Potion'', the band embarked on its largest tour to that point, performing in large theaters and 1,000-seat venues.{{cite news|title=The Keys to success|newspaper=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|first=Malcom X|last=Abram|date=September 17, 2006}} The Black Keys recorded covers of "[[The Wicked Messenger]]" for the [[I'm Not There (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] of the film ''[[I'm Not There]]'' and "If You Ever Slip" for ''[[The Hottest State]]'' soundtrack. {{Clear}} ===''Attack & Release'' and side projects (2007–2009)=== [[File:Dan Auerbach.jpg|thumb|left|Auerbach performing with The Black Keys in East London in March 2008]] In 2007, producer [[Danger Mouse (music producer)|Danger Mouse]] began working on a record for [[Ike Turner]] and asked The Black Keys to write a few songs for the project. The collaboration ultimately fell through and Turner later died in December 2007. The duo decided to turn the material they had written into their fifth studio album, ''[[Attack & Release]]'', and they asked Danger Mouse to produce the record.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/in-the-studio-the-black-keys-20080225|title=In the Studio: The Black Keys|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 25, 2008|accessdate=March 11, 2012}} The sessions saw the band transitioning away from their "homemade" ethos to record-making; not only was it the first time that the band completed an album in a professional studio,{{cite news|title=Attack & Release|newspaper=[[Monterey County Weekly]]|first=Stuart|last=Thornton|date=April 17, 2008}} but it was also the first time they hired an outside producer to work on a record.{{cite news|title=The Black Keys / Attack & Release (Nonesuch/Warner)|newspaper=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|first=Rob|last=Williams|date=April 19, 2008}} Danger Mouse supplemented the band's sound with instrumental flourishes and more polished production values.{{cite web|url=http://bostonherald.com//entertainment/music/music_news/2008/05/entering_danger_mouse_zone|title=Entering the Danger Mouse zone|work=[[The Boston Herald]]|first=Jed|last=Gottlieb|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=June 8, 2012}} Released on April 1, 2008, ''Attack & Release'' debuted at number 14 on the ''Billboard'' 200. Four singles were released: "[[Strange Times (The Black Keys song)|Strange Times]]", "[[I Got Mine (The Black Keys song)|I Got Mine]]", "Oceans and Streams", and "Same Old Thing". "Strange Times" was featured in the video games ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' and ''[[NASCAR 09]]''. "I Got Mine" is used as the theme song for Canadian police drama TV series ''[[The Bridge (Canadian TV series)|The Bridge]]''. The song was ranked number 23 on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s list of The 100 Best Singles of 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/24947047/the_100_best_singles_of_2008/6|title=The 100 Best Singles of 2008|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=December 25, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2013|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20081229022402/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/24947047/the_100_best_singles_of_2008/6|archivedate=December 29, 2008|deadurl=yes}} On October 17, 2008, The Black Keys was an opening act for fellow Akron-area band [[Devo]] at a special benefit concert at the [[Akron Civic Theatre]] for presidential candidate [[Barack Obama]]. [[Chrissie Hynde]] of the [[Pretenders (band)|Pretenders]], also an Akron native and Firestone High School graduate, followed their set.{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/news/devo-s-benefit-concert-whips-up-vote-1.118454|title=Devo's benefit concert whips up vote|publisher=Ohio.com|first=Malcolm X|last=Abram|date=October 17, 2008|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} In November, they toured through Europe together with [[Liam Finn]]. That month, the group released the concert video ''[[Live at the Crystal Ballroom]]'', which was filmed on April 4, 2008 at the group's show at [[Crystal Ballroom (Portland, Oregon)|Crystal Ballroom]] in Portland, Oregon. The video was produced by [[Lance Bangs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/live-at-crystal-ballroom-dvd|title=The Black Keys: Live at the Crystal Ballroom (DVD)|publisher=Nonesuch Records|accessdate=January 22, 2013}} [[File:The Black Keys Live at the Agora Cleveland Jan 30 2009.jpg|thumb|250px|The Black Keys performing at The Agora in January 2009]] Tensions grew within the band in 2009. Prior to Carney's divorce from his wife Denise Grollmus, Auerbach found it increasingly difficult to communicate with the drummer due to his antipathy for Grollmus. Auerbach said, "I really hated her from the start and didn't want anything to do with her." In February, Auerbach released his debut solo album, ''[[Keep It Hid]]''. Carney, who claimed Auerbach did not tell him about the side project, felt betrayed. Carney subsequently formed the indie band [[Drummer (band)|Drummer]], with whom he played bass guitar.{{cite web|url=http://www.magnetmagazine.com/2009/10/26/qa-with-the-black-keys-patrick-carney/|title=Q&A With The Black Keys’ Patrick Carney|work=[[Magnet (magazine)|Magnet]]|first=Eric T.|last=Miller|date=October 26, 2009|accessdate=March 24, 2012}} The group released its debut album ''[[Feel Good Together]]'' on September 29, 2009. The Black Keys reconciled later in the year. On June 6, 2009, they performed along with [[The Roots]], [[TV on the Radio]], [[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]], [[Antibalas Afrobeat Orchestra|Antibalas]], and other acts at the 2nd Annual Roots Picnic on the Festival Pier in [[Philadelphia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-roots-steal-the-show-from-black-keys-public-enemy-at-picnic-20090608|title=The Roots Steal the Show From Black Keys, Public Enemy at Picnic|work=Rolling Stone|first=Jonathan|last=Valania|date=June 8, 2009|accessdate=January 22, 2012}} They also joined the 9th annual [[The Independent Music Awards|Independent Music Awards]] judging panel to assist independent musicians' careers.{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/imajudges2010.asp |title=Independent Music Awards – 9th Annual Judges |publisher=Independentmusicawards.com |date= |accessdate=December 12, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://top40-charts.com/news/Charts-Awards/She-&-Him-The-Black-Keys-Mark-Hoppus-Aimee-Mann-And-Bettye-LaVette-Join-Judging-Panel-For-The-9th-Annual-Independent-Music-Awards/48785.html|title=She & Him, The Black Keys, Mark Hoppus, Aimee Mann And Bettye LaVette Join Judging Panel For The 9th Annual Independent Music Awards|publisher=Top40-Charts.com |date=May 27, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2013}} ''[[Blakroc]]'', a collaborative album featuring The Black Keys and several [[hip hop music|hip hop]] artists, was released in 2009 on [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]]. The project was supported and brought together by [[Damon Dash]], who is a big fan of the band. The album features rappers [[Mos Def]], [[Ludacris]], [[RZA]], [[Raekwon]], [[Pharoahe Monch]], [[Q-Tip (rapper)|Q-Tip]], [[NOE (rapper)|NOE]], [[Jim Jones (rapper)|Jim Jones]], [[Nicole Wray]], [[M.O.P.]], and the late [[Ol' Dirty Bastard]]. The album was recorded in [[Brooklyn]], New York. Auerbach said on the official Blakroc site, "Pat and I have been preparing for this record since we were 16."{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267409/black-keys-reveal-blakroc-hip-hop-project-details|title=Black Keys Reveal Blakroc Hip-Hop Project Details|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|first=David J.|last=Prince|date=September 14, 2009 |accessdate=February 19, 2013}} ===''Brothers'' (2010–2011)=== [[File:Black Keys Feb 2010 in Jacksonville.jpg|thumb|left|The Black Keys performing in February 2010, three months before the release of their breakthrough album ''[[Brothers (The Black Keys album)|Brothers]]'']] The group's sixth studio album, ''[[Brothers (The Black Keys album)|Brothers]]'', was released on May 18, 2010.{{cite web|author=Monday |url=http://www.directcurrentmusic.com/music-news-new-music/2010/2/22/shorts-punch-brothers-black-keys-runaways-movie-trash-can-si.html |title=Shorts: Punch Brothers, Black Keys, Runaways Movie, Trash Can Sinatras, Doves 'Best', Stone's 'Exile', Grace Potter – Music News / New Music – Direct Current |publisher=Directcurrentmusic.com |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=December 12, 2010}} Recorded primarily at [[Muscle Shoals Sound Studio]], the album was produced by The Black Keys and Mark Neill,{{cite web|url=http://theblackkeysfanlounge.com/2010/01/interview-mark-neill-on-recording-the-black-keys-new-album-2010/ |title=''The Black Keys Fan Lounge'' online |publisher=Theblackkeysfanlounge.com |date=May 18, 2010 |accessdate=December 12, 2010}} and was mixed by [[Tchad Blake]].{{cite web|url=http://theblackkeysfanlounge.com/2010/03/interview-tchad-blake-on-mixing-the-black-keys-blakroc-and-brothers-albums/ |title=''The Black Keys Fan Lounge'' online |publisher=Theblackkeysfanlounge.com |date=April 1, 2010 |accessdate=December 12, 2010}} The song "[[Tighten Up (The Black Keys song)|Tighten Up]]", the only track from the album produced by Danger Mouse, preceded the album as the lead single. The song became their most successful single to that point, spending 10 weeks at number one on the [[Alternative Songs]] chart and becoming the group's first single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], peaking at number 87.{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the black keys|chart=Hot 100}}|title=The Black Keys – Chart history: Hot 100|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=February 19, 2013}} The song also reached gold certification status.{{cite web|url=http://www.theblackkeys.com/news/record-certifications-around-world|title=Record Certifications Around the World|publisher=TheBlackKeys.com|date=October 26, 2012|accessdate=November 26, 2012}} The music video for "Tighten Up", directed by [[Chris Marrs Piliero]],{{cite web|title=The Black Keys - Tighten Up (Official Music Video)|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mpaPBCBjSVc|date=May 20, 2010|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} won the 2010 [[MTV Video Music Award – Breakthrough Video|MTV Video Music Award for Breakthrough Video]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/the-black-keys/519833/tighten-up.jhtml|title=VMA Playlist: All-Time Best Breakthrough Videos|year=2010|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} ''Brothers'' sold over 73,000 copies in the US in its first week and peaked at number three on the ''Billboard'' 200, their best performance on the chart to that point.{{cite web|title=The Black Keys' "Brothers" Debuts at No. 3 on Billboard Album Chart with Band's Best One-Week Sales Ever|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/the-black-keys-brothers-debuts-at-no-3-on-billboard-album-chart-bands-best-one-week-sales-ever-2010-05-26|date=May 26, 2010|publisher=[[Nonesuch Records]]|accessdate=February 6, 2011}} In total, the record sold 1.5 million copies worldwide, including 870,000 copies in the US,{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/04/arts/music/the-black-keys-change-gears-with-el-camino.html?pagewanted=all|title=First, Hit It Big. Then Change.|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|first=Alan|last=Light|authorlink=Alan Light|date=December 4, 2011|page=AR1|accessdate=December 7, 2011}} and it was certified double-platinum in Canada, platinum in the US, and gold in the UK. The Black Keys were among several artist judges at the 9th annual [[Independent Music Awards]] to support independent artists' careers.{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/2010judgebios.asp#auerbach|title=9th Annual IMA Artist Judges|publisher=[[Independent Music Awards]]|accessdate=July 26, 2011}} The band continued to gain exposure through continued song licensing, so much so that they were [[Warner Bros. Records]]' most-licensed band of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/513392/tightened-up-inside-the-black-keys-rise-to-arena-sized-fame|title= Tightened Up: Inside the Black Keys' Rise to Arena-Sized Fame|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|first=Jillian|last=Mapes|date=January 6, 2012|accessdate=February 19, 2013}} ''Rolling Stone'' placed ''Brothers'' at number two on its list of the best albums of 2010 and "Everlasting Light" at number 11 on the list of the year's best songs.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/30-best-albums-of-2010-20101213/the-black-keys-brothers-20101214|title=30 Best Albums of 2010: The Black Keys, 'Brothers'|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|author=Dolan, Jon, David Fricke, Will Hermes, Melissa Maerz, Jody Rosen, Rob Sheffield and Jonah Weiner|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-songs-of-2010-20101214/the-black-keys-everlasting-light-19691231|title=50 Best Songs of 2010: The Black Keys, 'Everlasting Light'|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|author=Dolan, Jon, David Fricke, Will Hermes, Melissa Maerz, Jody Rosen, Rob Sheffield, and Jonah Weiner|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' named The Black Keys the "Artist of the Year" for 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/articles/artist-year-black-keys|title=Artist of the Year: The Black Keys|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|first=Amanda|last=Petrusich|date=December 14, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012}} On January 8, 2011, the band appeared as the musical guest on American television sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/articles/watch-black-keys-triumphant-return-snl|title=Watch the Black Keys' Triumphant Return to 'SNL'|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin.com]]|publisher=Spin Media LLC|first=Marc|last=Hogan|date=December 5, 2011|accessdate=December 5, 2011}} At the [[53rd Grammy Awards]], ''Brothers'' and its songs won awards in three of the five categories they were nominated in; the band received honors for [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] (for ''Brothers'') and [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal|Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal]] (for "Tighten Up"), while [[Michael Carney (artist)|Michael Carney]], the band's creative director and Patrick's brother, won [[Grammy Award for Best Recording Package|Best Recording Package]] for designing the album's artwork.{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2011/02/grammy-awards-black-keys-on-being-one-of-the-evenings-wildcard-winners.html|title=Grammy Awards: Black Keys, on being one of the evening's wild card winners|work=[[Los Angeles Times|LATimes.com]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|first=Gerrick D.|last=Kennedy|date=February 13, 2011|accessdate=February 2, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=black+keys&title=&year=All&genre=All|title=Past Winners Search – Artist: Carney|work=[[Grammy Awards|GRAMMY.com]]|publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} [[File:Blackkeys022011.jpg|thumb|The Black Keys performing in Las Vegas in February 2011]] The band's sudden success proved overwhelming, as they found themselves booking additional promotional commitments and facing demand for additional touring dates. In January 2011, the group canceled concerts in Australia, New Zealand, and Europe, citing exhaustion, thus clearing out most of their touring schedule into April.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/the-black-keys--3/54603|title=Black Keys cancel tour dates because they are 'drained'|work=[[NME]]|date=January 18, 2011|accessdate=February 2, 2012}} Patrick Carney said, "We've been touring long enough to know when we're about to hit our breaking point." The desire to record another album soon after ''Brothers'' also led to the decision. Carney said, "We could have waited another year or so, and milked the ''Brothers'' album and kept touring, but we like bands, and our favourite bands growing up and even today, are bands that put out a lot of music and every album is different from the last." ''Brothers''{{'}} second single, "[[Howlin' for You]]", was a successful follow-up, achieving a gold certification in the US. The music video, directed by Chris Marrs Piliero,{{cite web|title=Howlin' for You Behind-the-Scenes|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qbdbhY9V1VY|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} parodied action movie trailers and starred [[Tricia Helfer]], [[Diora Baird]], [[Sean Patrick Flanery]], [[Christian Serratos]], [[Corbin Bernsen]], [[Todd Bridges]], and [[Shaun White]].{{cite web|title= Howlin' for You|url=http://www.theblackkeys.com/news/howlin-you|date=February 10, 2011|publisher=Warner Bros. Records|accessdate=March 31, 2011}}{{cite web|title=Howlin' for You: IMDB page|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1828981/|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} It was nominated for the 2011 [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Rock Video]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2011/best-rock-video/|title=MTV VMA Best Rock Video Nominees 2011|accessdate=January 10, 2012}} The Black Keys were nominated for three [[Billboard Music Award]]s: Top Alternative Artist, and Top Rock Album and Top Alternative Album for ''Brothers''.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/472097/full-2011-billboard-music-awards-finalists-list|title=Full 2011 Billboard Music Awards Finalists List|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|accessdate=February 20, 2013}} The group continued to make appearances at American music festivals throughout the year, playing at Bonnaroo, [[Kanrocksas Music Festival|Kanrocksas]], and [[Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival|Outside Lands]]. ===''El Camino'' (2011–2013)=== The group recorded their seventh studio album, ''[[El Camino (The Black Keys album)|El Camino]]'', from March to May 2011. Splitting time between touring and recording, the band spent 41 days at Easy Eye Sound Studio, which was opened in 2010 by Auerbach in the duo's new hometown of [[Nashville, Tennessee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2011/11/the-black-keys-brothers-in-arms/|title=The Black Keys: Brothers In Arms|work=[[American Songwriter]]|first=Andrew|last=Leahey|date=November 1, 2011|accessdate=December 8, 2011}} For the album, Danger Mouse reprised his role as producer and also contributed as a co-writer on all 11 songs. After struggling to translate the slower songs from ''Brothers'' to a live setting, the band decided to write more uptempo tracks for ''El Camino''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10769942|title=The Black Keys get back into the groove|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|first=Scott|last=Kara|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=December 8, 2011}} The record draws from popular genres from the 1950s–1970s,{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/julie-kocsis/the-black-keys-potential-_b_1144906.html|title=The Black Keys' Potential to Be America's New Favorite Rock Band|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|first=Julie|last=Kocsis|date=December 13, 2011|accessdate=December 13, 2011}} including [[rock and roll]],{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/the-black-keys-don-t-change-much-in-move-to/article_2d5e9153-6e21-5f45-9d10-e724e98e571f.html|title=The Black Keys don't change much in move to arena shows|work=STLtoday.com|publisher=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|first=Kevin C.|last=Johnson|date=April 26, 2012|accessdate=April 27, 2012}} [[glam rock]], [[rockabilly]], [[surf rock]], and [[soul music|soul]].{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|tab=review|id=r2324441|pure_url=yes}}|title=El Camino – The Black Keys|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|accessdate=December 5, 2011}} The band cited several retro acts as musical influences on the album, including [[The Clash]], [[The Cramps]], [[T. Rex (band)|T. Rex]], [[Ramones]], [[The Beatles]], [[Sweet (band)|Sweet]], [[The Cars]], and [[Johnny Burnette]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10769942|title=The Black Keys get back into the groove|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|first=Scott|last=Kara|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=December 8, 2011}} [[File:The Black Keys at MSG 3-22-12.jpg|thumb|left|The Black Keys performing at [[Madison Square Garden]] in March 2012]] "[[Lonely Boy (The Black Keys song)|Lonely Boy]]" was released in October as the album's lead single, accompanied by a popular [[One shot (music video)|one-shot]] music video of a man dancing and lip-syncing. The song became the group's best-charting single in several countries, reaching number 64 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, number 2 on the [[Australian Singles Chart]],{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=The+Black+Keys|title=Discography The Black Keys|work=australian-charts.com|publisher=Hung Medien|accessdate=February 14, 2012}} and number 33 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]].{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the black keys|chart=Billboard Canadian Hot 100}}|title=The Black Keys – Chart history: Billboard Canadian Hot 100|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=February 19, 2013}} The song was certified nine-times platinum in Canada, triple platinum in Australia, platinum in New Zealand, and gold in Denmark. The band returned to ''Saturday Night Live'' as a musical guest on December 3, 2011.{{cite journal|url=http://www.ohio.com/the330entertainment/abram/dec-5-2011-el-camino-should-keep-black-keys-on-road-to-success-1.248695|title=‘El Camino’ should keep Black Keys on road to success|journal=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|first=Malcolm X|last=Abram|date=December 5, 2011|accessdate=December 6, 2011}} ''El Camino'' was released three days later and received wide critical acclaim.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/el-camino/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for El Camino|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=December 1, 2011}} In the US, it debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and sold 206,000 copies in its first week, the highest single-week sales and (to that point) charting position the group had achieved in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/41927/michael-bubles-christmas-stays-atop-billboard-200-black-keys-hit-no-2|title=Michael Buble's 'Christmas' Stays Atop Billboard 200, Black Keys Hit No. 2|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|date=December 14, 2011|accessdate=February 19, 2013}} Many publications, such as ''Rolling Stone'' and ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' ranked ''El Camino'' among the best albums of the year, despite its late release.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-albums-of-2011-20111207/the-black-keys-el-camino-20111209|title=50 Best Albums of 2011: The Black Keys, 'El Camino'|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|author=Anderson, Stacey, Jon Dolan, David Fricke, Will Hermes, Monica Herrera, Jody Rosen, Rob Sheffield, and Simon Vozick-Levinson|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Suddath|first=Claire|title=The Top 10 Everything of 2011 - Black Keys, El Camino|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2101344_2101364_2101592,00.html|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=December 7, 2011|accessdate=December 13, 2011}} The album was certified double-platinum in Australia, Canada, and New Zealand; platinum in the US, UK, and Ireland; and gold in Belgium, the Netherlands, and France. [[File:The-Black-Keys-Coachella-4-20-12.jpg|thumb|250px|The Black Keys during their headline appearance at Coachella in April 2012]] In 2012, the group commenced the first headlining arena tour of its career,{{cite web|url=http://www.citybeat.com/cincinnati/blog-3072-review_the_black_keys_arctic_monkeys_at_us_bank_arena.html|title=Review: The Black Keys/Arctic Monkeys at US Bank Arena|work=[[Cincinnati CityBeat]]|first=Deirdre|last=Kaye|date=March 5, 2012|accessdate=March 11, 2012}} the [[El Camino Tour]], playing dates in Europe and North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/entertainment/music/2011/12/02/19059026.html|title=The Black Keys announces new tour|work=[[London Free Press|lfpress.com]]|publisher=[[Sun Media]]|first=Jane|last=Stevenson|date=December 3, 2011|accessdate=January 15, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/the-black-keys-announce-second-leg-of-north-american-tour-2012-01-09|title=The Black Keys Announce Second Leg of North American Tour|publisher=[[Nonesuch Records]]|date=January 9, 2012|accessdate=January 15, 2012}} After tickets went on sale, their show at [[Madison Square Garden]] sold out in 15 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2011/12/black-keys-sell-out-madison-square-garden-in-15-mi.html|title=The Black Keys Sell Out Madison Square Garden in 15 Minutes|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|publisher=Paste Media Group|first=Tyler|last=Kane|date=December 9, 2011|accessdate=January 4, 2012}} Just as it did on its previous tour, the group added bassist Gus Seyffert and keyboardist/guitarist John Wood as touring musicians in order to perform songs as close to their studio arrangements as possible.{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/popmusic/index.ssf/2012/03/the_black_keys_are_bigger_than.html|title=The Black Keys are bigger than ever as they return to Northeast Ohio to play The Q|work=[[The Plain Dealer|Cleveland.com]]|publisher=Cleveland Live LLC|first=John|last=Soeder|date=March 18, 2012|accessdate=March 19, 2012}} The album's second single, "[[Gold on the Ceiling]]", like its predecessor, went to number one on the Alternative Songs chart{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the black keys|chart=Alternative Songs}}|title=The Black Keys – Chart history: Alternative Songs|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=February 20, 2013}} and was certified platinum in Australia and Canada. The group headlined several music festivals throughout the year, including Catalpa Music Festival,{{cite web |title=Festival Face-Off|url=http://nymag.com/nightlife/barbuzz/82150/index1.html |work=[[New York (magazine)|NYMag.com]]|publisher=New York Media, LLC|first1=TJ|last1=Kosinski|first2=Vanita|last2=Salisbury|date=June 20, 2012|accessdate=May 1, 2013}} Coachella, Memphis in May, Lollapalooza, and [[Osheaga Festival|Osheaga]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} At the [[2013 Grammy Awards]], ''El Camino'' and "Lonely Boy" were nominated in five categories and were winners in three; the album won [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Album|Best Rock Album]], while "Lonely Boy" won [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance|Best Rock Performance]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Song|Best Rock Song]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/news/black-keys-artists-score-four-grammys-1.372289|title=Black Keys artists score four Grammys|work=Ohio.com|publisher=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|first=Malcolm X|last=Abram|date=February 11, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} The band began recording their eighth studio album in January 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1481570/black-keys-hint-at-new-album-plot-tour-with-flaming-lips|title=Black Keys Hint at New Album, Plot Tour with Flaming Lips|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|first=Jason|last=Lipshutz|date=January 7, 2013|accessdate=February 20, 2013}} ===''Turn Blue'' (2013–present)=== For their eighth studio album, ''[[Turn Blue (album)|Turn Blue]]'', the band once again collaborated with Danger Mouse, who co-produced and co-wrote the album. It was recorded primarily at [[Sunset Sound Recorders|Sunset Sound]] in Hollywood, California, from July–August 2013, with additional recording at [[Key Club Recording Company|Key Club]] in [[Benton Harbor, Michigan]], and Nashville's Easy Eye Sound in early 2014. The album was announced on March 21, 2014 via [[Mike Tyson]]'s [[Twitter]] account, with a link to an infomercial-style [[YouTube]] teaser video for their forthcoming album.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5944798/black-keys-announce-new-album-turn-blue-via-mike-tysons-twitter|title=The Black Keys Announce New Album 'Turn Blue' Via Mike Tyson's Twitter|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|first=Chris|last=Payne|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} Released on May 13, 2014, the record exhibits [[psychedelic rock]] and soul influences and features a more melancholy tone.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6084774/the-black-keys-defy-turn-blue-album-review-billboard|title=The Black Keys Defy Radio Trends on 'Turn Blue': Album Review|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|first=Mac|last=Randall|date=May 12, 2014|accessdate=May 12, 2014}} The first single, "[[Fever (The Black Keys song)|Fever]]" was released on March 24.{{cite web|url=http://news.radio.com/2014/03/21/black-keys-turn-blue-new-album-teaser/|title=The Black Keys Announce New Album ‘Turn Blue’ Due Out May 13th|work=Radio.com|publisher=[[CBS Local Media]]|first=James|last=Montgomery|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=March 21, 2014}} Their second single, "[[Turn Blue (song)|Turn Blue]]" was released on April 14.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/54756-the-black-keys-share-new-single-turn-blue/|title=The Black Keys Share Their New Song "Turn Blue"|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|first=Evan|last=Minsker|date=April 14, 2014|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} The album debuted at number one in the US and Australia, the band's first record to top the album charts in either country.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6092255/billboard-200-black-keys-michael-jackson-albums-rascal-flatts|title=The Black Keys Earn First No. 1 Album, Michael Jackson Debuts At No. 2|work=Billboard.com|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|date=March 21, 2014|accessdate=March 22, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://themusic.com.au/news/all/2014/05/17/the-black-keys-beat-michael-jackson-to-top-spot-of-albums-chart/|title=The Black Keys Score First Australian #1; Michael Jackson Settles for #3|work=themusic.com.au|publisher=Street Press Australia|author=Staff writer|date=May 17, 2014|accessdate=May 21, 2014}} ==Band members== * [[Dan Auerbach]] – guitar, vocals, bass guitar, piano, organ, keyboards, synthesizer (2001–present) * [[Patrick Carney]] – drums, percussion (2001–present) ;Touring musicians * [[Richard Swift (singer-songwriter)|Richard Swift]] – bass guitar, vocals (2014–present){{cite AV media |people=[[Zane Lowe|Lowe, Zane]] (presenter)|date=April 30, 2014|title=The Black Keys in session|medium=Radio broadcast|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01y8kqr|accessdate=May 5, 2014|time= ||publisher=[[BBC Radio 1]]}} * [[John Clement Wood]] – keyboards, vocals, organ, synthesizer, guitar, tambourine (2010–present) ;Former touring musicians * [[Nick Movshon]] – bass guitar (2010){{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2010/06/22/the_black_keys_pride_selves_as_unperfectionists/|title=The Black Keys pride selves as 'unperfectionists'|newspaper=[[Boston.com]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|first=Jake|last=Coyle|date=June 22, 2010|accessdate=April 24, 2012}} * Leon Michels – keyboards, organ, synthesizer, tambourine (2010) * Gus Seyffert – bass guitar, vocals (2010–2013) ==Discography== {{mainlist|The Black Keys discography}} * ''[[The Big Come Up]]'' (2002) * ''[[Thickfreakness]]'' (2003) * ''[[Rubber Factory]]'' (2004) * ''[[Magic Potion (album)|Magic Potion]]'' (2006) * ''[[Attack & Release]]'' (2008) * ''[[Brothers (The Black Keys album)|Brothers]]'' (2010) * ''[[El Camino (The Black Keys album)|El Camino]]'' (2011) * ''[[Turn Blue (album)|Turn Blue]]'' (2014) ==Awards and nominations== ===Grammy Awards=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Nominated work !! Award !! [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Song|Best Rock Song]] || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"|''Brothers'' || [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] || {{won}} |- | [[Grammy Award for Best Recording Package|Best Recording Package]] (awarded to creative director) || {{won}} |- | "Black Mud" || [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Instrumental Performance|Best Rock Instrumental Performance]] || {{nom}} |- | 2012 || "Dearest" || [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance|Best Pop Duo/Group Performance]] ||{{nom}} |- |rowspan="6"|2013||rowspan="3"|"Lonely Boy" ||
